articles.headline: A New Kind of Bank Run Tests Old Safeguards
articles.snippet: Savers used to respond to financial panics with runs on banks. Now the targets are the securities that have replaced banks as the prime generators of credit.
articles.abstract: Savers used to respond to financial panics with runs on banks. Now the targets are the securities that have replaced banks as the prime generators of credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few generations ago, savers responded to financial panics with runs on banks, and even healthy institutions could fail if they could not raise enough cash quickly enough.

articles.headline: Is Fraud O.K., if You Help Just a Little?
articles.snippet: The Refco case is raising the question of how much responsibility is borne by those who are complicit in fraud cases.
articles.abstract: The Refco case is raising the question of how much responsibility is borne by those who are complicit in fraud cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: It takes a team to pull off a good corporate fraud. Of course, the manager is responsible, but what about the people — and the companies — who just helped out a little? It may be that they are the only ones with enough cash to pay billion-dollar judgments.

articles.headline: Product Packages Now Shout to Get Your Attention
articles.snippet: Consumer goods companies are using their products’ packages as 3-D ads to grab shoppers’ fickle attention.
articles.abstract: Consumer goods companies are using their products’ packages as 3-D ads to grab shoppers’ fickle attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last 100 years, Pepsi had changed the look of its can, and before that its bottles, only 10 times. This year alone, the soft-drink maker will switch designs every few weeks.

articles.headline: Mortgage Losses Echo in Europe and on Wall Street
articles.snippet: On Thursday, stocks on Wall Street suffered their biggest one-day decline since February. Indexes fell more than 2 percent across Asia in early trading today.
articles.abstract: On Thursday, stocks on Wall Street suffered their biggest one-day decline since February. Indexes fell more than 2 percent across Asia in early trading today.
articles.lead_paragraph: Turmoil in the home loan market ricocheted from the United States to Europe and back again yesterday as stocks on Wall Street suffered their biggest one-day decline since February, reflecting growing concerns about tightening credit worldwide.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Mark Landler

articles.headline: The Feud Behind the Sale of Barneys New York
articles.snippet: Behind what seemed like a well-orchestrated triumph in the apparent deal to sell Barneys New York was a bitter rift between the C.E.O. and board of its owner, Jones Apparel Group.
articles.abstract: Behind what seemed like a well-orchestrated triumph in the apparent deal to sell Barneys New York was a bitter rift between the C.E.O. and board of its owner, Jones Apparel Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the outside world, it looked like a well-orchestrated triumph: the clothing powerhouse Jones Apparel Group appeared poised yesterday to sell Barneys New York, the ultra-hip department store, for more than twice what the company paid for it, nearly $1 billion.

articles.headline: Well-Off Fleeing Iraq Find Poverty and Pain in Jordan
articles.snippet: In a painful new reality for an important part of Iraq’s population, professionals who fled elsewhere in the Middle East are finding it difficult to make ends meet.
articles.abstract: In a painful new reality for an important part of Iraq’s population, professionals who fled elsewhere in the Middle East are finding it difficult to make ends meet.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 9 — After her husband’s killing, Amira sold a generation of her family’s belongings, packed up her children and left behind their large house in Baghdad, with its gardener and maid.

articles.headline: Facing a Furor, Pakistan Rejects Emergency Rule
articles.snippet: Gen. Pervez Musharraf backed away from declaring a state of emergency after a gathering storm of pressure.
articles.abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf backed away from declaring a state of emergency after a gathering storm of pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 9 — Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, was on the brink of declaring a state of emergency in his increasingly volatile country but backed away after a gathering storm of media, political and diplomatic pressure, Pakistani officials acknowledged on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Salman Masood

articles.headline: Shaky Markets Prompt Rumors of Who’s in Trouble
articles.snippet: Amid a volatile market, rumors of shaky hedge funds or overexposed private equity firms are running rampant as investors try to guess which will fall next.
articles.abstract: Amid a volatile market, rumors of shaky hedge funds or overexposed private equity firms are running rampant as investors try to guess which will fall next.
articles.lead_paragraph: The global stock and bond markets these days seem to be playing a giant game of hide and seek.
